thread.title: No price increase at outpatient dental clinics, says Health Ministry - Nation
thread.title_full: No price increase at outpatient dental clinics, says Health Ministry - Nation | The Star Online

author: thestar.com.my
title: No price increase at outpatient dental clinics, says Health Ministry - Nation
text:
PETALING JAYA: There is no increase in prices for patients seeking treatment at government outpatient dental clinics, says the Health Ministry.
Health director-general Datuk Dr Noor Hisham Abdullah said that the increase was imposed only for patients needing inpatient treatment and opting to be admitted in the first or second class ward.
Dr Noor Hisham was clarifying press reports yesterday that quoted an internal circular saying that the cost of extractions would go up from the current RM1 to RM15, scaling from RM2 to RM55, and fillings from RM2 to RM25.
The new rates were set to take effect from Feb 1, but the circular stated that the date of implementation would be delayed until March 1.
“The internal circular is meant to inform staff about the increase in charges, which have not taken into account the subsidy,” Dr Noor Hisham said in a telephone interview yesterday.
He noted that there was no first, second or third class for outpatient treatment and that all Malaysian citizens seeking treatment at government dental clinics still paid the same rate of RM1 for extractions, RM2 for scaling and RM2 for fillings.
However, the actual cost to the Government, RM15, RM55 and RM25 respectively, would be stated in the patients’ bills to show the amount subsidised by the Government, he added.
Dr Noor Hisham said in a statement later that the charges stated in Fees (Medical) Order 1982 had not been revised for 35 years to reflect the actual current cost.
The current basic treatment cost was thus updated in the Fees (Medical) Order (Amended) 2017, he said.
“The Government is committed to providing the high subsidy to the people, including outpatient dental treatment,” he said, adding that the subsidy rate had increased.
